newsitem.title: UK: UK government mulls changing car number plate system.
newsitem.headline: UK government mulls changing car number plate system.

text.p: Transport Secretary Sir George Young said on Tuesday the government was to look at the possibility of changing Britain's car number plate system after industry complaints that it harms competitiveness.
Young published a consultative document detailing a range of possible alternatives to the present system under which the initial letter of plates for new cars changes each August.

The industry says this system, which will continue until 2004 unless the government intervenes, is inefficient and costly because it leads to a huge swell of car sales each August, forcing manufacturers to stockpile cars in advance.
"We have...agreed to look at the possibility of bringing the present cycle to an end sooner and replacing it with a system which would avoid the August sales peak," Young said in a statement.
He said that if the government did introduce a new system before 2004, it "would look to the industry to finance the additional costs involved".

Among the options canvassed in the consultative document are keeping a letter which identifies the age of cars but changing it every three or six months, number plates which show the area of the country where a car was purchased, and plates which identify both age and area.
The Transport Department is asking for comments on the document by March 21.
